issues.title: Attachment Circuit - Terminology Change
issues.author: jlivingood
issues.body: Suggesting changing from 'circuits' - since mobile and other IP networks are packet-based. Maybe some other term can be used.

comments.author: jlivingood
comments.body: I see that AC is used in linked docs - perhaps this is a 3GPP term?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Hi Jason,

"Attachment circuit" is an established concept in IP/MPLS networks, you can see, for example, 

* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4026#section-6.1
* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4364#section-3.1
* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8049#section-3
* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-opsawg-teas-common-ac/
* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit/
* https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-opsawg-ntw-attachment-circuit/
* etc.

The term "circuit" is also used in the transport layer, e.g., circuit breaker (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8084/)

I agree that it is unfortunate that "circuit" was picked at the first place, but reusing this concept helps gluing various pieces that are already out there and also help generalizing the applicability. 

For example, an AC can be UNI or NNI. Hence, s/ac/access network may not be adequate to mirror that scope as well.

What about "network attachment"?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: “Network attachment” is great

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Thanks Dan. Went with "network attachment" in the abstract for now.

comments.author: jlivingood
comments.body: +1 to network attachment - great idea!

comments.author: markusa
comments.body:
First collection of tools. Feel free to add others that we can integrate and describe in the document.

- L4S
- Network-Slicing/URSP
- NEF/Network-APIs

issues.title: Add some more text about FCC/regulatory
issues.author: boucadair

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: https://www.fcc.gov/document/fcc-restores-net-neutrality-0

issues.title: fairness to users
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8517#section-3.10

careful wording: wastage of data. Sending data that won't be consumed.

comments.author: luismcontreras
comments.body:
Possible text to add:

"Different application-centric strategies can be not efficient form the perspective of the usage of resources. This fact can produce not desirable effects in the overall utilization of the network. Situations such as infinite scrolling, prefetching, or high-resolution content delivery can result on a wastage of resources that can be harmful from a global perspective, i.e., taking into consideration the different applications running on the network."

comments.author: luismcontreras
comments.body: The documents I commented for this Issue are not plublicly available, so cannot be referred to, I guess. We can keep this on hold, or close the issue and re-open it in case the documents become available at some point of time.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Thanks, Luis. Let's close this one then.

comments.author: luismcontreras
comments.body:
Re-opening this issue since Telecom Infra Project has just publicly released the material.

The reports are here: https://telecominfraproject.com/tip-releases-qoe-measurement-framework-and-graduates-metaverse-ready-project-group/

So, now, the point for this issue to check relevance of these reports for out draft. I take the action.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @luismcontreras, do you think there is something useful that is worth to share in our drafts (blob, for example)?

issues.title: PvD comment from Tommy Pauly
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
De : Tommy Pauly <tpauly@apple.com> 
Envoyé : mardi 4 juin 2024 17:32
À : BOUCADAIR Mohamed INNOV/NET <mohamed.boucadair@orange.com>
Cc : tirumal reddy <kondtir@gmail.com>
Objet : Re: Feedback on the use of PvD Use for Collaborative Networking



Hi Med,

PvDs are starting to be implemented more now, for the proxy discovery use case, so I think we will see a push there.

Overall, it seems a bit odd to just put that information in the appendix, as opposed to next to the other provisioning mechanisms, as it is a standards-track mechanism. I also think it makes sense to discuss whether you need the details of information to go directly into RAs or DHCP, or if it makes sense to have this be in a separate service (like PvD, or like how CAPPORT had a separate server that you talk to to get the information).

Thanks,
Tommy

issues.title: Add some explanation for the need to have a reliability flag
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: @sridharangirish91, can you please propose some text to https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/blob/main/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.md to motivate the need to have reliability flag? Thanks

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: I don't think it is possible to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic in QUIC. How is rate-limit policy enforced by networks today for QUIC traffic ?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> I don't think it is possible to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic in QUIC. 

For network to distinguish, the sender would have to set a bit somewhere.  DSCP bit, a certain QUIC short CID, IPv6 hop-by-hop option, *something*.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic. The hop-by-hop option also faces deployment challenges. I am not aware of any deployments where CID is used by networks to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic.

I suggest to remove it and keep the 00 version simple.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic.

Better tell the L4S proponents!

comments.author: jlivingood
comments.body:
> DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic. 

That is not correct. Most ISPs will re-write DSCP on ingress flows. For NQB, ISPs are preserving DSCP-45 e2e. 

> The hop-by-hop option also faces deployment challenges. I am not aware of any deployments where CID is used by networks to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic.

If unreliable vs reliable the same as NQB vs QB?

comments.author: jlivingood
comments.body:
> DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic. 

That is not correct. Most ISPs will re-write DSCP on ingress flows. For NQB, ISPs are preserving DSCP-45 e2e. 

> The hop-by-hop option also faces deployment challenges. I am not aware of any deployments where CID is used by networks to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic.

If unreliable vs reliable the same as NQB vs QB?

comments.author: jlivingood
comments.body:
> DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic. 

That is not correct. Most ISPs will re-write DSCP on ingress flows. For NQB, ISPs are preserving DSCP-45 e2e. 

> The hop-by-hop option also faces deployment challenges. I am not aware of any deployments where CID is used by networks to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic.

If unreliable vs reliable the same as NQB vs QB?

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic.
> 
> Better tell the L4S proponents!

DSCP values can be modified by at any place in the network (see https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9435.html#section-4.3) and I don't think the application can be trusted to set the correct DSCP value.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > DSCP values cannot be typically applied for incoming traffic.
> 
> That is not correct. Most ISPs will re-write DSCP on ingress flows. For NQB, ISPs are preserving DSCP-45 e2e.
> 
> > The hop-by-hop option also faces deployment challenges. I am not aware of any deployments where CID is used by networks to distinguish between reliable and unreliable traffic.
> 
> If unreliable vs reliable the same as NQB vs QB?

Yes, reliable would be mapped to QB and unreliable to NQB but the network has no visibility of such information on a QUIC flow which could have both unreliable and reliable streams.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Yes, reliable would be mapped to QB and unreliable to NQB but the network has no visibility of such information on a QUIC flow which could have both unreliable and reliable streams.

That's the call of the app. The considerations in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/[draft-ietf-tsvwg-nqb-27](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-tsvwg-nqb-27#name-dscp-marking-of-nqb-traffic)#name-dscp-marking-of-nqb-traffic may be followed. The marking will thus be visible.

Of course, I don't think we say this is the only way to do it and that a network have to create policers for both.

issues.title: Throughput advice
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
rate-limit =  {
     cir: uint,    ; Mbps
     cbs: uint,    ; bytes
     ? eir: uint,  ; Mbps
     ? ebs: uint,  ; bytes
     ? pir: uint,  ; Mbps
     ? pbs: uint   ; bytes
   }

I assumed cir and cbs are sufficient to be conveyed to the client, what is the need to convey the other rates and how is the client supposed to react to each of the rates differently ?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> I assumed cir and cbs are sufficient to be conveyed to the client

Yes, these are mandatory

> what is the need to convey the other rates and how is the client supposed to react to each of the rates differently ?

A discussion about this is provided in https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#name-overview-of-network-rate-li (see the last para). See also the last two par in 4115.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
Which two last paragraphs are you referring in 4115 ?
It is not clear to me how the client will react differently by learning the eir, ebs, pir and pbs rates ?
For instance, in case of 1r2c, the client only has to enforce the traffic does not exceed cir and cbs. what will it do with the other two parameters eir and ebs ?
How will the client identify the burst duration using cbs ?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
I was referring to,

> The metering/marker defined here is different from those in [[RFC2697](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2697)]
>    and [[RFC2698](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2698)].  It is different from [[RFC2697](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2697)] in that it is a two-
>    rate, three-color marker.  In contrast, [[RFC2697](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2697)] is a single-rate
>    marker.  It is different from [[RFC2698](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2698)] in the way its parameters are
>    defined, which allows a better handling of in-profile traffic for
>    predominant service scenarios over a wider range of traffic
>    parameters.
> 
>    Furthermore, the algorithm described here eliminates the need for the
>    CE to shape its traffic to a certain peak information rate (PIR), as
>    might be the case for the marker defined in [[RFC2698](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2698)] when the value
>    for the peak burst size (PBS) is smaller than that for the committed
>    burst size (CBS).

These parameters are already for the provisioning of CEs for some services. See, e.g., https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc8466/ (search for svc-bandwidth).

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: Thanks for the info, I was aware that PBS could be slower than CBS; it will helpful to add a pointer to this paragraph.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Sure. Created https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/pull/45 to address this.

issues.title: Comments on CDDL
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
1.  In tc, the field tc: uint has the same name as the containing structure, which could lead to confusion. please rename this field.
2.  In opf and ff, you may want to use "false" instead of "0".

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Good catch. Please see #40 

BTW, in order to save some space, I guess we need to have tree values for direction (n2h, h2n, both). Otherwise, we will need to repeat the same parameters twice to cover the case where the same policy is applied for both directions.

issues.title: Add RSOO support for NRLP options (DHCP)
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
See rfc6422: the relay may be configured with the rate-limit as it is on-path. It will then supply the info to the server, then back to the client.

Consider adding NRLP to the registry at: https://www.iana.org/assignments/dhcpv6-parameters/dhcpv6-parameters.xhtml#options-relay-supplied 

Also, add a provision to include NRLP in "DHCPv6 Options Permitted in the RADIUS DHCPv6-Options Attribute" (https://www.iana.org/assignments/dhcpv6-parameters/dhcpv6-parameters.xhtml#dhcpv6-options-attribute)

issues.title: Nit
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
A Single-Rate, Three-Color Marker {{?RFC2697}} uses CIR, CBS, and EBS.
Nit> The above line needs to be updated to include EIR.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> A Single-Rate, Three-Color Marker {{?RFC2697}} uses CIR, CBS, and EBS.
> Nit> The above line needs to be updated to include EIR.

The text is correct per RFC2697:

>    The srTCM meters a traffic stream and marks its packets
>    according to three traffic parameters, Committed Information Rate
>    (CIR), Committed Burst Size (CBS), and Excess Burst Size (EBS)

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
Got it, Thanks. However, I don't see EIR defined in RFC2697 but then why is it included in the CDDL ?

E:
: When set to "1", this flag indicates the presence of Excess Information Rate (EIR).
: When set to "0", this flag indicates that EIR is not present.

rate-limit =  {
  cir: uint,          ; Mbps
  cbs: uint .gt 0,    ; bytes
  ? eir: uint,        ; Mbps ==> This needs to be removed. 
  ? ebs: uint .gt 0,  ; bytes
  ? pir: uint,        ; Mbps
  ? pbs: uint .gt 0,  ; bytes
}

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
That's defined in RFC4115, for example:

>    The operation of the marker is described by two rate values.  The
>    committed information rate (CIR) and the excess information rate
>    (EIR).  CIR and EIR define the token generation rate of a token
>    bucket with size that is equal to committed burst size (CBS) and
>    excess burst size (EBS), respectively.

We need to cover the various combination out there.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: we may need to clarify that EIR is defined in RFC 4115.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
We already have: 

> The document leverages existing technologies for configuring policies in provider networks. [Appendix A](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#sec-overview) provides a brief overview of how inbound policies are enforced in ingress network nodes. **The reader may refer to [[RFC2697](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#RFC2697)], [[RFC2698](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#RFC2698)], and [[RFC4115](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#RFC4115)]** for examples of how various combinations of Committed Information Rate (EIR), Committed Burst Size (CBS), Excess Information Rate (EIR), Excess Burst Size (EBS), Peak Information Rate (PIR), and Peak Burst Size (PBS) are used for policing.

issues.title: Usage of the rate-limity policy by an application
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
we should add some text to explain how an application developer would leverage the blob. 

For example, we can add the following text to justify the use of the new metadata:

1. Applications can send data at a rate beyond the CIR up to the PIR when the network is not congested. If network feedback (e.g., packet loss, delay) indicates congestion, the application can scale back to the CIR. Otherwise, it can use the PIR for temporary throughput boosts. 
2. Applications can send short-term bursts of data that exceed the committed burst size CBS up to the PBS if there’s no congestion. This is useful for scenarios where short, high-throughput bursts are needed.
3. Applications can ensure that their sending rate never exceeds the PIR and that their short-term bursts of traffic never exceeds PBS.

issues.title: Usage of the CDDL metadata in DHCP, RA and PvD
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: We will need to update the discovery draft to explain how the metadata defined in CDDL can be leveraged by DHCP, RA and PvD.

issues.title: Define groups: (C*+E*) or (C*+P*)
issues.author: tireddy2

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: I couldn't find RFCs to refer but in practical deployments, can there be a case where a packet exceeds CBS but is within PBS, so is EBS used in that case to have a more lenient window (like packets > CBS but < EBS to be treated with lower(lowest) priority and drop the ones that exceed PBS?

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: my understanding is (EIR, EBS) and (PIR and PBS) are mutually exclusive.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Tiru is right. As indicated in the blob ID, typical combinations are these in https://s3-docs.fd.io/vpp/23.06/developer/corefeatures/policer.html. 

Other implems (Juniper) can be seen here as well: https://www.juniper.net/documentation/us/en/software/junos/cos/topics/task/cos-configuring-tricolor-marking-policers.html or https://www.juniper.net/documentation/us/en/software/junos/routing-policy/topics/concept/policer-overview.html

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: That's very helpful, thanks a lot Med :)

issues.title: Need to classify catgeories
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: -	I don't think there is need to classify categories of traffic now, this would definitely create some confusion, specially how it is done in the draft. For example, what does real-time mean? Is this p2p conversational media? Or does live streaming also fall into that category?  Another would be Bulk traffic , what does that even mean? Are you doing more that Diff serv or mimicking that?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: Other points are defined in separate issues: #63 #62 #61

comments.author: sridharangirish91
boucadair
comments.body:
Thanks @sridharangirish91. Please see also #69 (and the example of categories defined for example by the GSMA). 

I suggest we only include "any" TC for -00 and continue the discussion about other TC values that we might include in future version.

issues.title: reactive policy
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body: -	Should there be mentioned already in the Abstract for the reactive policy as an additional example the limited capacity due to varying radio connection conditions (now there are mentioned the overload and DDoS attach mitigation)? The “issue with RAN resources” is mentioned though in the Sample Deployment Cases, so don’t know if this is already enough.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: the old issues are  split into individual issues #58 #59 #60

issues.title: Scope description
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > What is meant with the scope per host and per subscriber (what role is subscriber in the IETF terms)? Is there a target to define the traffic flow granularity (even per application level)..?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Updated the text for better clarity. 

Note that we do already have:

> The throughput advice is bound to a subscriber, a host, and traffic category, not individual flows. This is consistent with, e.g., [Section 8.1.1](https://rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9330#section-8.1.1) of [[RFC9330](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#RFC9330)] which states that "there has never been a universal need to police the rate of individual application flows".

issues.title: details about means/validity, etc.
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > Without knowing the actual means to deliver this Throughput Advice info to host (or app?) this might/or might not be relevant: There is not mentioned anything about the applicability of this Throughput Advice info: Is it valid until the further notice/updated policy (possible infinitively or 1 sec) or should there be defined some timing value in the throughput advice object (the policy valid for the next 20 sec or 30min..?)?

issues.title: nit
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > Minor typo in line 123: “…how various combinations of Committed Information Rate (EIR),..”, the abbreviation not correct (should be CIR?).

issues.title: What is committed?
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > -	What is committed? In Scone charter there is no commitment from any party involved, right? Let’s not create GBR, MBR discussion here.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: We are using IETF existing terms here.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/commit/61469eee3aed8ca1604e2a1c4ce044e3ea4d02de

issues.title: EBS/PBS Intended Use for specific traffic category
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > It is not clear from the draft if Excess Burst or Peak Burst is needed or how those can be used for a specific category of traffic.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The text says these are optional. The text cites examples where these helps the outbound policy to maintain in-profile traffic.

The current text says these are bound to the traffic category.

issues.title: Level of details
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: > Also I am not sure I understand the complexity of providing such detailed information from the network to the client, we even have hard time providing just the bitrate information. How would the network provide and maintain the commitments its making to burst information and peak rate information. - Moreover, I think the authors should be able to provide enough experimental information to justify the need for such detailed information from the network to the client.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The text provides pointers to examples where these parameters are already shared with customers: 

> These rate-limits can be shared with customers when subscribing to a connectivity service (e.g., "A YANG Data Model for Layer 2 Virtual Private Network (L2VPN) Service Deliver" [[RFC8466](https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#RFC8466)]).

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: This text covers the reasoning for having the various parameters: https://boucadair.github.io/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/draft-brw-scone-throughput-advice-blob.html#name-throughput-parameters

issues.title: Define few traffic categories
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: Should we leverage categories such as those defined in https://www.gsma.com/newsroom/wp-content/uploads/NG.135-v1.0-1.pdf

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: I could move the traffic categories to the appendix and quote the above doc. We could stick with the existing ones but leave it extendable for future?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The current PR removed all values except 0 ("any") from the draft but leaves 1-63 for future assignments.

I think it is better for -00. We can prepare text for future versions.

issues.title: per-flow scope
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Rate-limit are usually not on per-app basis (net-neutrality, etc.)

For example, RFC9330 says: 

> 
> " However, there has never been a
>    universal need to police the rate of individual application flows --"

Per-flow rate-limits induces also deployment concerns as to how resources can be partitioned, how the partition is bound to a specific volatile flow without? etc.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: Also, is there a way/need to introduce specific limits without knowing the identity of the flow? If so, it is a breach of privacy. If not, it is based on the traffic category (if at all signaled), and we can defer it to future?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
From Vasilenko Eduard <vasilenko.eduard@huawei.com>

> 
> Hi Experts,
> IMHO: you are missing the critical parameter in the SCONE specification: the number of sessions on the bottleneck scheduler (it looks like the scheduler is called “flow policy” in the draft).
> 
> Per-flow performance is not possible for hardware routers and switches – it is too expensive, hardware routers are 3x cheaper, switches are 5x cheaper compared to flow-based devices (FW, IPS, DPI, LB, etc).
> 
> Per-scheduler performance (possible for routers and switches) is useless without knowing how many flows are sharing it. It is a divider to understand what is possible to push for the particular flow on the host.
> 
> Of course, it is a big challenge to how hardware routers or switches would calculate the number of sessions. But better to push the problem out of SCOPE territory.
> It would be possible to say: “SCOPE will be ready when the hardware router would be ready”. (if ever)
> 
> IMHO: it is better to include “the number of sessions” in the SCOPE specification.
> 
> PS: Software routers are typically multi-functional our days (IPS, DPI, and everything else on board), flow-based forwarding is possible.
> Moreover, all 3GPP wireless IP forwarding is based on software only – no acceleration has been done for 3GPP.
> Unfortunately, fixed broadband is based on BRAS/BNG which is actually a hardware router – it could not be flow-based.

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: If my understanding of it is correct, this would be a signal from routers about the congestion in their AQM. In that case, this could potentially be a signal that really doesn't need to identify the flow but just send to all the flows going through that device, be it a CPE or a shaper. Might be worth including since it doesn't need to id specificities of the flow. But what are we signaling here? Queuing latency so that it can be added to cc rtt? Can't the router just set the ECN bit instead of signaling something so dynamic?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> If my understanding of it is correct, this would be a signal from routers about the congestion in their AQM. In that case, this could potentially be a signal that really doesn't need to identify the flow but just send to all the flows going through that device, be it a CPE or a shaper.

Good observations, @sridharangirish91.

> Might be worth including since it doesn't need to id specificities of the flow. But what are we signaling here? Queuing latency so that it can be added to cc rtt? Can't the router just set the ECN bit instead of signaling something so dynamic?

I'm not sure this is actually in scope.  Also, this reminds me other signaling approaches at L2, e.g., https://www.ieee802.org/1/files/public/docs2022/new-congdon-IETF-113-sidemeeting-0322-v01.pdf

comments.author: sridharangirish91
comments.body: I agree, this is not in the scope. Thanks for the link :)

issues.title: Comments
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
1. Also, one or more throughput advice instances may be returned for a given traffic direction. Each of these instances may cover a specific traffic category. Examples of such instances are discussed in {{sec-ex}}.

Comment> Is this line required (now that the draft does not discuss multiple traffic categories) ?

2. How applications running over a host can learn the bitrates associated with a network attachment. Typically, this can be achieved by invoking a dedicated API. However, the exact details of the API is OS-specific and, thus, out of scope of this document.

Comment> It is not clear whether OS-specific APIs are required not. I would remove the last line. MASQUE and QUIC based proposals don't require OS-specific API.

3. The services or applications that are delivered over a network attachment. Whether one or multiple services are bound to the same network attachment is deployment specific.

Comment> I don't get how the above line is relevant for this draft. What is the use case for a single service being bound to a network attachment ? 

The network has no clue whether it is a single or multiple applications with QUIC (and TLS ECH).

4. Adaptive Application Behavior: : Discovery of intentional policy applied on network attachements when such information is not made available during the service activation or when network upgrades are performed. Adaptive applications will use the information to adjust their behavior. : Concretely, applications are supposed to have access to all throughput advice instances and would, thus, adjust their behavior as a function of scope and traffic category indicated in a throughput policy (all traffic, streaming, etc.). An application that couples multiple flow types will adjust each flow type to be consistent with the specific policy for the relevant traffic category. : Likewise, a host with multiple network attachments may use the discovered throughput advice instances over each network attachment to decide how to distribute its flows over these network attachments (prefer a network attachment to place an application session, migrate connection, etc.). That's said, this document does not make any recommendation about how a receiving host uses the discovered policy.

Comment> I see the discussion on traffic category (which can be avoided for now).

5. I don't see a need for "Security Considerations" Section to focus on DDoS.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> 1. Also, one or more throughput advice instances may be returned for a given traffic direction. Each of these instances may cover a specific traffic category. Examples of such instances are discussed in {{sec-ex}}.
> 
> Comment> Is this line required (now that the draft does not discuss multiple traffic categories) ?

It is as it can include an advice for traffic direction (even with tc=any).

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> 3\. How applications running over a host can learn the bitrates associated with a network attachment. Typically, this can be achieved by invoking a dedicated API. However, the exact details of the API is OS-specific and, thus, out of scope of this document.
> 
> Comment> It is not clear whether OS-specific APIs are required not. I would remove the last line. MASQUE and QUIC based proposals don't require OS-specific API.

I'm not sure about this claim for MASQUE/etc. Please refer to https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-eddy-scone-api/

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> 5\. The services or applications that are delivered over a network attachment. Whether one or multiple services are bound to the same network attachment is deployment specific.
> 
> Comment> I don't get how the above line is relevant for this draft. What is the use case for a single service being bound to a network attachment ?

A single flow may multiplex multiple types (audio, video, interactive, sharing file, etc.). The initial point was that it is up to the application to the bind the rate limit policy per packet. However, this is too subtle for -00. We can delete that part.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> 5\. I don't see a need for "Security Considerations" Section to focus on DDoS.

DDoS is provided as an example to illustrate the use of rate limit + mention that other mechanisms can be used. This is a sec cons section. Anyway,  soften these mentions at https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/commit/2962238d34031cb4f3b2756a48ae04e5ba5e8e79.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> 7\. Adaptive Application Behavior: : Discovery of intentional policy applied on network attachements when such information is not made available during the service activation or when network upgrades are performed. Adaptive applications will use the information to adjust their behavior. : Concretely, applications are supposed to have access to all throughput advice instances and would, thus, adjust their behavior as a function of scope and traffic category indicated in a throughput policy (all traffic, streaming, etc.). An application that couples multiple flow types will adjust each flow type to be consistent with the specific policy for the relevant traffic category. : Likewise, a host with multiple network attachments may use the discovered throughput advice instances over each network attachment to decide how to distribute its flows over these network attachments (prefer a network attachment to place an application session, migrate connection, etc.). That's said, this document does not make any recommendation about how a receiving host uses the discovered policy.
> 
> Comment> I see the discussion on traffic category (which can be avoided for now).

OK, done at https://github.com/boucadair/draft-xxx-ac-rate-policy-discovery/pull/73/files#diff-ab358ab0ffa13e672eedeaa457634187ee628bbab438b0bafd7df2d648ef7e4b

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > 1. Also, one or more throughput advice instances may be returned for a given traffic direction. Each of these instances may cover a specific traffic category. Examples of such instances are discussed in {{sec-ex}}.
> > 
> > Comment> Is this line required (now that the draft does not discuss multiple traffic categories) ?

Yes, but the draft does not define a "specific traffic category". The following line can be removed: 
Each of these instances may cover a specific traffic category.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Yes, but the draft does not define a "specific traffic category". The following line can be removed:

ACK. See #75

I agree an API (framework) would be required but doesn't that delve into implementation details and is that needed in a blob definition draft though?

This is typically why the current text says this is out of scope.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > > > 3. How applications running over a host can learn the bitrates associated with a network attachment. Typically, this can be achieved by invoking a dedicated API. However, the exact details of the API is OS-specific and, thus, out of scope of this document.
> > > >    Comment> It is not clear whether OS-specific APIs are required not. I would remove the last line. MASQUE and QUIC based proposals don't require OS-specific API.

I prefer to remove the the bullet: How applications running over a host can learn the bitrates associated with a network attachment. Typically, this can be achieved by invoking a dedicated API. However, the exact details of the API is OS-specific and, thus, out of scope of this document.

It is an unnecessary distraction not relevant to the draft. The WG may adopt a solution like TRAIN which does not require any OS-specific API. I don't see how this bullet is useful to progress the draft.

Even TRAIN has the following: 

"A signal that is sent for a specific
   flow is likely enforced at a different scope.  The extent of that
   scope is not carried in the signal."

I will keep  the sentence for -00. If this triggers discussion, that's good to have. Thanks.

issues.title: Comments on SCONE Analysis
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
1.

Atomic configuration: characterizes whether the throughput advice can be learned using very few packets and whether any change of the policy would require to full policy to be shared or only the relevant instance.

Comment> I can't parse the last part of the line. I suggest the following text:

Atomic configuration: Indicates whether the throughput advice can be learned using very few packets and whether changes to the policy require sharing the entire policy or just the relevant part.

2. Replace "Guard against random advice injection" with "Guard against random advice injection by an on-path attacker".

3. We will have to elaborate "Mobility (guard against changing 5-tuple)". please elaborate the attack.
   I presume you are referring to a scenario where an malicious app keeps changing the 5-tuple to evade rate-limit enforcement by the   
   network.

4. what is meant by "proactive signaling" ?

5. Applicable to any transport protocol => I suggest to remove it, the charter is specific to QUIC, I don't think a solution will be selected solely on the basis that it is applicable for other transport.

6. We may want to explain the meaning of "cascaded environments"

7. Require flow inspection and tracking (network)

Comment> How does inspecting the QUIC flow impact security and how is tracking possible ?

8. What do you mean "Require steering policies on the host" ?

9. I would change "Overhead of unauthenticated re-encryption" to "Overhead of double encryption"
   The status of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-masque-quic-proxy/ is experimental, It also discusses "identity" mode which  
   does not modify the packet in any way.

10. we should also include protocol ossification, zero-trust security (authorized network element must provide the throughput advice), privacy (does not reveal any details about the app and server identity).

issues.title: Another comment on the Analysis
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
1. 
To that aim, NRLP:

    Requires an OS API to expose the signal to applications, and ensure application fairness: An OS can provide more accurate available bandwidth to applications through the API, making implementation easier for applications that don't require dedicated bandwidth measurement.

Comment> It will be considered as an disadvantage of NRLP. If PvD is used, the app just needs to learn the PVD ID from OS (which is not specific to NRLP) and the PvD additional information can be retrieved by the app itself (without any dependency on OS). I prefer a solution where OS is involved, but that does not mean NRLP cannot be deployed without any support from OS.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: fair comment. fixed in #79

issues.title: Subscriber specific rate-limit policies
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
Each subscriber in a mobile network may have different QoS policies depending on their subscription plan. Similarly, in home networks, devices can be assigned different priorities, see https://www.tp-link.com/in/support/faq/1601/. Furthermore, Cisco routers support user-group-based QoS policies, enabling tailored traffic prioritization for user groups (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/iproute_pi/configuration/15-mt/iri-15-mt-book/iri-sgt-based-qos.pdf).

The NRLP draft should discuss mechanisms like solicited Router Advertisements (RAs) https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8273.txt and DHCP responses that enable unique rate-limit configurations per endpoint. Without addressing it, the scope of the draft will be restricted to applying a common rate-limit policy for all endpoints attached to the network.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> Each subscriber in a mobile network may have different QoS policies depending on their subscription plan. Similarly, in home networks, devices can be assigned different priorities, see https://www.tp-link.com/in/support/faq/1601/. Furthermore, Cisco routers support user-group-based QoS policies, enabling tailored traffic prioritization for user groups (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/iproute_pi/configuration/15-mt/iri-15-mt-book/iri-sgt-based-qos.pdf).

ACK, I'm afraid this will introduce more complexity at this stage for the scone case.

FWIW, the full structure of the rate-limit is per type (port, class, node, etc.) as defined in draft-ietf-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit, for example:

  ```
            +--rw svc-pe-to-ce-bandwidth {vpn-common:inbound-bw}?
              |  +--rw bandwidth* [bw-type]
              |     +--rw bw-type      identityref
              |     +--rw (type)?
              |        +--:(per-cos)
              |        |  +--rw cos* [cos-id]
              |        |     +--rw cos-id    uint8
              |        |     +--rw cir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw cbs?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw eir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw ebs?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw pir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw pbs?      uint64
              |        +--:(other)
              |           +--rw cir?   uint64
              |           +--rw cbs?   uint64
              |           +--rw eir?   uint64
              |           +--rw ebs?   uint64
              |           +--rw pir?   uint64
              |           +--rw pbs?   uint64
              +--rw svc-ce-to-pe-bandwidth {vpn-common:outbound-bw}?
              |  +--rw bandwidth* [bw-type]
              |     +--rw bw-type      identityref
              |     +--rw (type)?
              |        +--:(per-cos)
              |        |  +--rw cos* [cos-id]
              |        |     +--rw cos-id    uint8
              |        |     +--rw cir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw cbs?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw eir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw ebs?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw pir?      uint64
              |        |     +--rw pbs?      uint64
              |        +--:(other)
              |           +--rw cir?   uint64
              |           +--rw cbs?   uint64
              |           +--rw eir?   uint64
              |           +--rw ebs?   uint64
              |           +--rw pir?   uint64
              |           +--rw pbs?   uint64
```




> The NRLP draft should discuss mechanisms like solicited Router Advertisements (RAs) https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8273.txt and DHCP responses that enable unique rate-limit configurations per endpoint. Without addressing it, the scope of the draft will be restricted to applying a common rate-limit policy for all endpoints attached to the network.

The network cannot mandate how resources will be partitioned within a local network because that's out of its administration scope. The signal that we are providing right now is a good progress: "this is an aggregate that is shared with others". 

Are there specific considerations you have in mind that we can better indicate?

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > The NRLP draft should discuss mechanisms like solicited Router Advertisements (RAs) https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8273.txt and DHCP responses that enable unique rate-limit configurations per endpoint. Without addressing it, the scope of the draft will be restricted to applying a common rate-limit policy for all endpoints attached to the network.
> 
> The network cannot mandate how resources will be partitioned within a local network because that's out of its administration scope. The signal that we are providing right now is a good progress: "this is an aggregate that is shared with others".
> 
> Are there specific considerations you have in mind that we can better indicat



> > Each subscriber in a mobile network may have different QoS policies depending on their subscription plan. Similarly, in home networks, devices can be assigned different priorities, see https://www.tp-link.com/in/support/faq/1601/. Furthermore, Cisco routers support user-group-based QoS policies, enabling tailored traffic prioritization for user groups (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/iproute_pi/configuration/15-mt/iri-15-mt-book/iri-sgt-based-qos.pdf).
> 
> ACK, I'm afraid this will introduce more complexity at this stage for the scone case.
> 
> FWIW, the full structure of the rate-limit is per type (port, class, node, etc.) as defined in draft-ietf-opsawg-teas-attachment-circuit, for example:
> 
> ```
>           +--rw svc-pe-to-ce-bandwidth {vpn-common:inbound-bw}?
>             |  +--rw bandwidth* [bw-type]
>             |     +--rw bw-type      identityref
>             |     +--rw (type)?
>             |        +--:(per-cos)
>             |        |  +--rw cos* [cos-id]
>             |        |     +--rw cos-id    uint8
>             |        |     +--rw cir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw cbs?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw eir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw ebs?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw pir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw pbs?      uint64
>             |        +--:(other)
>             |           +--rw cir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw cbs?   uint64
>             |           +--rw eir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw ebs?   uint64
>             |           +--rw pir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw pbs?   uint64
>             +--rw svc-ce-to-pe-bandwidth {vpn-common:outbound-bw}?
>             |  +--rw bandwidth* [bw-type]
>             |     +--rw bw-type      identityref
>             |     +--rw (type)?
>             |        +--:(per-cos)
>             |        |  +--rw cos* [cos-id]
>             |        |     +--rw cos-id    uint8
>             |        |     +--rw cir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw cbs?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw eir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw ebs?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw pir?      uint64
>             |        |     +--rw pbs?      uint64
>             |        +--:(other)
>             |           +--rw cir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw cbs?   uint64
>             |           +--rw eir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw ebs?   uint64
>             |           +--rw pir?   uint64
>             |           +--rw pbs?   uint64
> ```
> 
> > The NRLP draft should discuss mechanisms like solicited Router Advertisements (RAs) https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8273.txt and DHCP responses that enable unique rate-limit configurations per endpoint. Without addressing it, the scope of the draft will be restricted to applying a common rate-limit policy for all endpoints attached to the network.
> 
> The network cannot mandate how resources will be partitioned within a local network because that's out of its administration scope. The signal that we are providing right now is a good progress: "this is an aggregate that is shared with others".
> 
> Are there specific considerations you have in mind that we can better indicate?

It will be helpful to explicitly mention how such endpoint-specific mechanism already supported by DHCP/RA will complement the current aggregate approach. I suggest adding text to say the proposed mechanism also works for endpoint-specific signaling which would provide additional granularity (similar to the way MASQUE and QUIC based solutions). I propose the following text:

To enhance flexibility in applying rate-limiting policies and better accommodate diverse endpoint QoS requirements, mechanisms such as solicited Router Advertisements (RAs) [RFC 8273] and endpoint-specific DHCP responses can be employed. These unicast responses enable granular signaling of rate-limit policies to individual endpoints, facilitating differentiated rate-limit configurations. However, this draft does not prescribe how resources should be partitioned within local networks, as such considerations fall outside its scope.

pulls.title: NRLP is Permitted in the RADIUS DHCPv4-Options Attribute
pulls.author: boucadair

comments.body:
```suggestion
* **Does not suffer from penalizing the proxy** which could serve both good and bad clients (e.g., launching Layer 7 DDoS attacks).
```

pulls.title: Including reliability bit to NRLP blob + Initial text for host OS incentive
pulls.author: sridharangirish91
pulls.body:
Unreliable traffic can have different bandwidth constraints due to no retransmits (and mostly it is fire-and-forget real-time but discardable data) and nature of it means we can have different policies for unreliable traffic during reactive event. Assigning the unassigned bit for this, if it is available.

Added initial text for OS deployment incentives

comments.body: @sridharangirish91: I wonder whether it makes more sense to define "R" as a TC value.

Hey Med,

I initially thought of that but things in TC seems to be nature of the application data but the reliability is more of a stream parameter, which is broader.

For eg. Real-time traffic can be both reliable (keyboard and mouse input) and unreliable (video P frames) - both can be from the same source (chat window in a presentation or a virtual desktop)

That's why kept a separate flag which can be treated globally above TC.

We actually need to separate 
* flags to control data that is enclosed in the options
vs
* characteristics of the flow themselves.

I will merge this PR, but will think about how to better articulate this in the spec.
Thanks Med
See #17

pulls.title: Update IANA sections + add a note about the extensibility of PvD

pulls.title: Alternative mechanisms
pulls.author: markusa
pulls.body:
Attempt to address #20.

This is a living PR that will receive multiple commits over time.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body:
The structure looks good thanks.

However,  I still think there is complementarity.

comments.body:
```suggestion
# Alternative/Complementary Mechanisms
```

```suggestion
In the event of bottlenecks in a network, there are other mechanisms that provide information or help to reserve resources. These can be used within the bottleneck network or, in some cases, across network boundaries. The following sections give examples of such mechanisms and provide background information.
```

```suggestion
Low Latency, Low Loss, and Scalable Throughput (L4S) is an architecture defined in {{RFC9330}} to avoid queuing at bottlenecks by capacity-seeking congestion controllers of senders. L4S support addresses the investigated use case of this document, which considers rate limiting, which typically involves queuing discipline at the rate limiting bottleneck. If all involved elements (UE, network, and service) support L4S, the use of Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) provides the measure used to inform the network protocol and/or service endpoints in use of impending congestion. Congestion detection and reaction may require some few RTTs, though to adjust to the network forwarding conditions.
```

```suggestion
One measure for guaranteeing resources in networks is network slicing. This is achieved by configuring certain resources , including adequate QoS setup for communication streams, which are taken into account in packet schedulers along the transport path, e.g., the RAN air interface.
```

```suggestion
Network slicing is considered by the 3GPP for 5G {{TS-23.501}} (an equivalent can be achieved in 4G by configuring QFI values), the IETF {{RFC9543}} for transport networks, and BBF {{TR-470}} for wireline access. A realization model in transport networks is detailed in {{?I-D.ietf-teas-5g-ns-ip-mpls}}.
```

```suggestion
L4S {{L4S}} can be used for the realization of a network slice. Network slices properties (e.g., throughput) can be retrieved from an operator network by third parties via a network API {{network_api}} (e.g., 3GPP NEF).
```

```suggestion
L4S {{L4S}} can be used for the realization of a network slice. Network slices properties (e.g., throughput) can be retrieved from an operator network or configured by third parties via a network API {{network_api}} (e.g., 3GPP NEF).
```
Shouldn't we emphasize also the configuration of network slices, e.g. by VoD providers, to achieve smooth playback?
This can be mentioned as an example.

```suggestion
Low Latency, Low Loss, and Scalable Throughput (L4S) is an architecture defined in {{RFC9330}} to avoid queuing at bottlenecks by capacity-seeking congestion controllers of senders. L4S support addresses the investigated use case of this document, which considers rate limiting, which typically involves queuing discipline at the rate limiting bottleneck. If all involved elements (UE, network, and service) support L4S, the use of Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) provides the measure used to inform the network protocol and/or service endpoints in use of impending congestion. Congestion detection and reaction may require a few RTTs to adjust to the network forwarding conditions.
```

```suggestion
As of 3GPP Rel. 18 (5G Advanced, {{TS-23.501}}), L4S is also defined for the 5G system (5GS) and can be used by UE and its services, and for external parties of the 5GS by exposure of congestion information.
```

```suggestion
One measure for guaranteeing resources in networks is network slicing. This is achieved by configuring certain resources like adequate QoS setup for communication streams, which are taken into account in packet schedulers along the transport path. e.g., the RAN air interface.
```

```suggestion
Network slicing is considered by 3GPP for 5G {{TS-23.501}} (an equivalent can be achieved in 4G by configuring QFI values), by IETF {{RFC9543}} for transport networks, and by BBF {{TR-470}} for wireline access. A realization model in transport networks is detailed in {{?I-D.ietf-teas-5g-ns-ip-mpls}}.
```

```suggestion
UE Route Selection Policy (URSP) is a feature specified in 3GPP to match and forward traffic based upon a selection descriptor and a route descriptor as further detailed in {{TS-23.503}}.
```

```suggestion
Specified traffic descriptors may be:
```

```suggestion
Specified route selection descriptors: must contain PDU Session Type Selection (e.g., IPv4v6 or IPv6) and may contain the following:

```
PDU type is mandatory since rel 16 (wasn't in release 15)

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
URSP rules that contain both descriptors can be announced from the provider network to a UE or preconfigured in the UE, possibly subscription-based. These rules can be used to identify services in the UE and to provide routes with explicit  characteristics. URSP rules might also be triggered by the usage of network APIs {{network_api}} and combined with network slicing {{ns}}, for example.
```

```suggestion
Approaches based on middleboxes are generally not recommended due to their inherent limitations, in terms of performance, scalability, redundancy, etc. Moreover, the management and operation of such middleboxes remain unclear, which can motivate operational issues and responsibilities.
```

reviews.body: Most of the changes look good.

reviews.author: tireddy2
reviews.body: I think security considerations section also needs to be updated to discuss about PvD.

comments.body:
This is to focus on the extensibility feature of PvD.

PvD can provide the required information to locate a network API and thus negotiate more "metadata"-related operation, especially for the host to network direction. That direction is out of scope of scope; we may remove this if it is confusing.
Please remove it.

Deal!

Shouldn't we highlight that PvD object can be easily extended?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
Citing the exact text was initially meant to avoid interpreting the text.

Updated the text to include a summary as suggested by Tiru to shorten the text.

reviews.author: tireddy2
reviews.body:
I suggest to summarize the text from BERC and FCC instead of repeating it, we can say the following: 

BEREC:
ISPs can’t block or slow internet traffic, except for legal reasons, network security, or congestion, and all traffic must be treated equally.

FCC:
Net neutrality rules stop ISPs from blocking, slowing, or prioritizing internet content for money. The FCC oversees internet service and allows some exceptions, like for security and emergencies.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The techniques discussed in the document offer the following security benefit: An OS can identify the type of application (background, foreground, streaming, real-time, etc.) and enforce appropriate network policies, even if a misbehaving application tries
```
